Bungie didn't sell it actually. It's quite complicated, I'll try to get a big picture for you:

Bungie first made Halo: Combat Evolved independently. It was supposed to be this game and that's all. Turned out the success of it was far over what they expected. Soon enough, they decided to make a trilogy out of it. In the meanwhile, Halo caught the attention of Microsoft Studios. Bungie and Microsoft Studios made an agreement to work on the next games together, and thus, Microsoft had a hand on Halo from the second game of the series. After making Halo 3, Bungie decided that they did not wish to push the Halo franchise further and said that Reach would be the last Halo game made by them. However, As stated above, Microsoft has rights on the Halo franchise, and they decided that they wanted to push it further. Thus, they created 343 Industries (after 343 Guilty Spark), a Microsoft Studios subdivision who's only purpose is to make new Halo games. 343 industries made Halo Wars, worked in cooperation with Bungie for Halo Reach and then made Halo 4, starting a second trilogy for the franchise.

So basically, Bungie didn't sell the Halo franchise. They just decided to "quit the project".
